verses.text: King Belshazzar made a great feast for a thousand of his lords, and drank wine in front of them.
verses.comment: Belshazzar, likely co-regent with Nabonidus, hosts a lavish feast, showing royal arrogance similar to other rulers in biblical history (cf. Esther 1:3).

verses.text: Belshazzar, under the influence of wine, ordered that the gold and silver vessels taken from the temple in Jerusalem by his father Nebuchadnezzar be brought in, so that he and his nobles, wives, and concubines might drink from them.
verses.comment: Using holy vessels for profane purposes showed contempt for God, reminiscent of profanation of holy things warned against throughout Scripture.

verses.text: So they brought in the gold vessels that had been taken from the sanctuary in God’s house in Jerusalem, and the king and his lords, wives, and concubines drank from them.
verses.comment: This act is a direct desecration of the holiness of worship, echoing other biblical warnings about treating sacred things with respect.

verses.text: They drank wine and praised the gods of gold and silver, bronze, iron, wood, and stone.
verses.comment: Idol worship is condemned throughout Scripture; note the contrast with worship directed toward the one true God.

verses.text: Immediately, the fingers of a human hand appeared and wrote on the plaster of the wall of the king’s palace, opposite the lampstand. The king saw the back of the hand as it wrote.
verses.comment: God intervenes physically as in other places where He directly inscribes His message, reminiscent of the writing of the Law (cf. Ex. 31:18).

verses.text: Then the king’s color changed, and his thoughts alarmed him. His knees knocked together and his legs gave way.
verses.comment: Physical fear and trembling in the face of divine revelation is a regular reaction in biblical accounts (cf. Dan. 2:1; Ex. 34:29-30).

verses.text: The king called aloud for the enchanters, Chaldeans, and astrologers. He said to the wise men of Babylon, ‘Whoever reads this writing and tells me its meaning will be clothed with purple, have a gold chain around his neck, and be the third ruler in the kingdom.’
verses.comment: Seeking answers from wise men parallels earlier chapters. The reward underscores the desperation and importance of understanding the message.

verses.text: Then all the king’s wise men came in, but they could not read the writing or make known its meaning to the king.
verses.comment: Again, human wisdom is insufficient before God’s mysteries. Divine revelation exceeds human understanding.

verses.text: Then King Belshazzar was greatly alarmed, his face grew even paler, and his nobles were perplexed.
verses.comment: Repeated reference to the king’s fear highlights his powerlessness and foreshadows judgment.

verses.text: When the queen heard the voices of the king and his nobles, she entered the banquet hall and said, ‘O king, live forever! Don’t let your thoughts trouble you or your face turn pale.’
verses.comment: The entrance of the queen suggests wisdom outside the group of the king’s advisors. Her respectful address is typical of royal protocol.

verses.text: There is a man in your kingdom who has the spirit of the holy gods. In the days of your father, illumination, knowledge, and wisdom like the wisdom of gods was found in him. King Nebuchadnezzar made him chief of the magicians, enchanters, Chaldeans, and astrologers.
verses.comment: Daniel is credited with supernatural wisdom. Notice parallels with Joseph in Pharaoh’s court (Gen. 41:38).

verses.text: Because an extraordinary spirit, knowledge, and the ability to interpret dreams and explain mysteries were found in this Daniel, whom the king named Belteshazzar. Now let Daniel be called, and he will show the interpretation.
verses.comment: Daniel’s gifts tie to divine favor and reveal God’s use of chosen individuals to communicate His will—an echo of prophecy.

verses.text: Then Daniel was brought before the king. The king said to him, ‘Are you that Daniel, one of the exiles from Judah, whom my father the king brought from Judah?’
verses.comment: The emphasis on Daniel’s exile recalls Israel’s history and the prophetic significance of God’s people in foreign lands.

verses.text: I have heard that the spirit of gods is in you, that insight and extraordinary wisdom are found in you.
verses.comment: Even pagan kings acknowledge the presence of divine wisdom in God’s servants—a theme throughout Daniel’s narrative.

verses.text: Now the wise men and astrologers have been brought before me to read this writing and make known its interpretation, but they could not show what it means.
verses.comment: This verse reemphasizes human inadequacy apart from God’s revelation.

verses.text: But I have heard that you can give interpretations and solve mysteries. If you can read the writing and explain it, you will be clothed in purple, have a gold chain around your neck, and be the third ruler in the kingdom.
verses.comment: Rewards for wisdom continue the motif of God exalting His faithful ones among the nations (cf. Joseph, Gen. 41:42).

verses.text: Then Daniel answered the king, ‘You may keep your gifts or give your rewards to someone else. Nevertheless, I will read the writing for the king and make known its interpretation.’
verses.comment: Daniel’s refusal of rewards underscores the purity of his service and parallels Christ’s rejection of worldly powers (cf. Mt. 4:9-10).

verses.text: O king, the Most High God gave sovereignty, greatness, glory, and majesty to Nebuchadnezzar your father.
verses.comment: Daniel sets God as supreme over kings, echoing themes both in Daniel and in Romans 13 about God granting rulers their power.

verses.text: Because of the greatness He gave him, all peoples, nations, and languages trembled and feared before him. Whomever he wished he killed, and whomever he wished he kept alive; whomever he wished he exalted, and whomever he wished he humbled.
verses.comment: Describes universal authority, reflecting God’s sovereignty extended through earthly rulers.

verses.text: But when he became arrogant and his heart was hardened with pride, he was deposed from his royal throne and his glory was taken away.
verses.comment: Sin of pride leads to downfall, as seen throughout the biblical narrative (cf. Prov. 16:18).

verses.text: He was driven away from people, had his mind made like an animal, and his dwelling was with wild donkeys. He was fed grass like cattle, and his body was drenched with the dew of heaven, until he recognized that the Most High God rules over the kingdoms of men and sets over them whomever He chooses.
verses.comment: The transformation echoes the consequences of rebellion against God; conversion and repentance lead to restoration—a motif seen in salvation history.

verses.text: But you, Belshazzar his son, have not humbled your heart, although you knew all this.
verses.comment: Responsibility to learn from previous warnings is clear—echoed in Hebrews 3 about the danger of hardened hearts.

verses.text: Instead, you have exalted yourself against the Lord of heaven. You brought the vessels from His house before you, and you, your lords, your wives, and your concubines have drunk wine from them. You have praised gods of silver and gold, bronze, iron, wood, and stone, which do not see, hear, or know. But you have not honored the God in whose hand your breath and all your ways are.
verses.comment: Judgment comes for unrepentant idolatry. A reminder that all life is sustained by God alone.

verses.text: Therefore, He sent the hand, and this writing was inscribed.
verses.comment: God’s direct intervention signifies the seriousness of the judgment.

verses.text: And this is the writing that was inscribed: MENE, MENE, TEKEL, and PARSIN.
verses.comment: The Aramaic words are left untranslated for emphasis, showing how prophecy sometimes requires interpretation.

verses.text: This is the interpretation of the message: MENE – God has numbered your kingdom and finished it.
verses.comment: Divine sovereignty in measuring kings and nations; cf. Acts 17:26. God sets and removes rulers according to His purpose.

verses.text: TEKEL – You have been weighed on the scales and found lacking.
verses.comment: Imagery of scales is used throughout Scripture to convey divine judgment; cf. Ps. 62:9.

verses.text: PERES – Your kingdom is divided and given to the Medes and Persians.
verses.comment: Prophetic fulfillment of the succession of empires, as foreseen in earlier visions.

verses.text: Then Belshazzar commanded, and Daniel was clothed with purple, a gold chain was placed around his neck, and he was proclaimed third ruler in the kingdom.
verses.comment: Despite Daniel's unwillingness, earthly rulers reward prophets. This point anticipates how true faithfulness is often recognized but not always fully understood (cf. Luke 6:26).

verses.text: That very night Belshazzar the Chaldean king was killed.
verses.comment: Judgment was immediate, confirming God’s control over kingdoms and kings.

verses.text: And Darius the Mede received the kingdom, being about sixty-two years old.
verses.comment: Transfer of power fulfills previous prophecy of succession (see Dan. 2:39). This change symbolizes God’s guiding hand in historical events; Christians are reminded to look for fulfillment of prophecy, both literal and spiritual, and to trust in God’s ultimate plan.
